Do they really think that all the restriction of science to the observable can only make it weaker than other approaches? Can you always rely on the common sense of an someone who is not stupid/silly no matter what the topic is?

 i) materialistic evolution isn't a good model to begin with, (there is more than the material) in the way life came about.
 ii) I don't read that quote that way at all.
 To give an example... a hypothetical.
 Say science said that the earth's geographical land masses were once all connected by land bridges (this was an actual theory who's name escapes me at present). And a church comes along and says "Yes, this is how God formed the earth.... so that the animals all boarded onto the ark via land-bridges etc, and this church builds many rationales around the then current science. Then, 40 years down the track, there's a paradigm shift, we no longer hold that there were land bridges, but the continents themselves were directly joined to each other. Then, what happens to that church that rested it's theology in part on science. Science shifts all the time; I've no problem with that.
 
 It is why the Orthodox Church differs fundamentally in its approach to understanding God from the western churches. We actuall view the Catholic and Protestant churches as merely two sides of the same coin; both trying to use rationalistic argumens to understand God.
 You can, but there is a limit to this; this is because God is infinite, and therefore ultimately unknowable - but we can glimpse Him.
 We believe in noetic knowledge.

I have a book with pi expressed to 110 decimal places. I've seen it expressed to 1000 decimal places.
 
 The easiest to remember an approximation of pi is the fraction 22/7 or 3.1429. Handy when the caculator battery is dead.
 
 It's actually 3.1415926535897932384626438327950288419716939937510582007494 or thereabout!
 
 The Egyptians used pi (knowingly or not) in constructing pyramids.
 
 It will never equal 3.
Alan Ryan

I.
 How do you apply 'common sense' to experiences beyond the common?

 I have a lot of respect for "common sense" but it is sometimes a poor guide
 to the facts of a case. There are many cases where the explanation for 
 a particular event turns out to be "counter-intuitive". Here's an example: following common sense, the idea that an intelligent father and mother will have even more intelligent children and so on until after a few generations a family of geniuses appears, seems quite plausible. But this common sense approach is flawed because it takes no account of a statistical phenomenon
 known as "regression towards the mean"
 This phenomenon is unrelated to inheritance and the progression of time:
 applied to the example I've given, it might indicate that the mother of an
 exceptionally intelligent son and daughter would tend to be closer to the mean than her children.
unkerpaulie

i think this issue is terribly trivial. look at the context of the whole thing. a cubit is a very rough measure, basically the length from your elbow to your fingertip. the length can vary slightly depening on how your arm or wrist is bent. the units smaller than a cubit was a span (the width of your open hand from thumb to pinky) and inch (the length of a finger joint). there was no fractional relation between the different measures, and certainly no way of measuring 0.1415927 of a cubit. the measurements were rounded off to the nearest half at best.
 
 to compare the results of such measurements with our modern equipment, and then gloat about their inaccuracies, is rather childish, in my opinion
Big Orn

 to compare the results of such measurements with our modern equipment, and then gloat about their inaccuracies, is rather childish, in my opinion

 There was no standard for measurement in that regard in those days.
 
 For instance 1 cubit is about 18 inches making ten of them about 10 cubits.
jim's trucking

One cubit = 1
 Two cubit = 8
 Three cubit = 27
 Four cubit = 64
 Five cubit = 125
 Six cubit = 216
 Seven cubit = 343
 Eight cubit = 512
 
 etc
 
 10 cubit = 1000
 
 30 cubit = 27,000
 
 This makes just as much sense as pi=3!
 
 I don't believe the Bible was meant to be interpreted as implying that pi=3. It's a simple matter of men approximating measurements...like saying, "I brought 40 wagonloads of wheat" doesn't imply an exact amount.
 
 Was that a level teaspoon or a full teaspoon?
 
 Who was King when the foot was defined as a unit of measurement?

 See my post 14, I actually defend you.
 
 It did take a while to work out what you meant from Post #1, and because I know that you stated already, elsewhere that you know this 'example' not to be one used by creationists.
 
 But you needed, I believe, to re-state it in this thread; owing to the fact that not everyone reads all posts in all threads.
 
 However, getting back to the 'common sense' issue, I'd still like you to explore the idea of how you can apply common sense to something beyond the common?
 
 God is, (for those who believe in Him), essentially unknowable. We don't know, in our experience of God, or, I should say, we don't have, a common measure. For instance, you can compare your parents to other parents around, and even when you become a parent, apparently! You can't do that with concepts of God, or, even of creation. Which is why Fr Seraphim Rose said this about Genesis “Some Protestant fundamentalists tell us it is all (or virtually all) 'literal.” But such a view places us in some impossible difficulties: quite apart form our literal or non-literal interpretation of various passages, the very nature of the reality which is described in the first chapters of genesis the very creation of all things) makes it quite impossible for everything to be understood 'literally'; we don't even have words, for example, to describe 'literally' how something can come from nothing. How does God “speak”? - does He make a noise which resounds in an atmosphere that doesn't yet exist?” (Genesis Creation and Early Man, p69).

Close_slave_can

Nobody (and I mean nobody) is saying pi=3 using the bible. Everyone would reject the argument. Some would reject the argument only because common sense tells them the argument is pathetic. Some people would also reject the argument because they have issues with using the bible to make any sort of conclusion about the physical world. This is playing it safe because if you rely on common sense then would be disagreements over what arguments are pathetic as the arguments got more complicated. If you play it safe you are forced to get humbler conclusions but you get more consensus with other people playing it safe. The legal system works the same way. A judge does not hand out sentences based directly on how "evil" they think the criminals actions are he uses rules. In the right circumstances strict rules are fine.
